awd_titl_txt: Morphologically Complex Data Collection and Analysis for Improving Lexicographic Models
awd_abstract_narration:
Analytic dictionaries provide information on the possible and impossible sound combinations and words and clause structures found in individual languages.  Linguists and cognitive scientists mine analytic dictionaries to uncover knowledge about word meaning and cultural significance of places, things, and actions and how these are referred to by speakers.  These dictionaries are also useful for discovery of universally predictable or newly discovered grammatical patterns.  This project collects data to create an analytic dictionary of a language with unusually complex verb morphology.  The original fieldwork conducted with elder birth speakers for this project adds crucial information on the structure of the language, which in turn informs various subfields of linguistics such as historical linguistics, comparative linguistics, morphology, and syntax. This project supports education and diversity, engaging the Native American elders, teachers, and learners in creating a high-quality, comprehensive, and enduring language resource. 

The project expands current lexicographic models to deal with complex verb morphology.  The project reviews existing lexical databases to locate gaps in entries and analyzes and fills gaps through information collected via interviews of elder speakers of endangered languages.  These elders hold key pieces of lexical and grammatical knowledge that have not been documented elsewhere.  The investigator adds this newly collected information to the existing in a data format that is easily revised and augmented as new data becomes available.  Research conducted under this project implements a language documentation method that ensures that current and future learners and researchers have the opportunity to access newly documented lexical items, which provide the necessary data for the development of scientific language materials.  These materials can be used by the nonacademic community for language and culture revitalization.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The University of Alaska Faribanksʼ project titled “Morphologically Complex Data Collection and Analysis for Improving Lexicographic Models” was funded by a one-year grant from the National Science Foundationʼs Dynamic Languages Infrastructure program with Keri Eggleston as PI. Under this project, a model was developed for creating a dictionary of Tlingit which organizes words under a common root entry. Within the root entry, relationships between words are presented in a hierarchical manner, making explicit which forms are derived from which. Under this project, an existing database of 1,100 conjugated Tlingit verbs was converted and exported to the TLex dictionary compilation software, which allows for the organization of this data into a hierarchical structure. Research with elder language consultants was conducted throughout the project year to fill in gaps in existing documentation, adding these new words to the database. Also incorporated into the database was a collection of 1,500 Tlingit example sentences with English translations and accompanying audio recordings of elders reading the examples. This resource previously existed only in the Sealaska Heritage Institute archives and through this project has been made available online at http://ankn.uaf.edu/~tlingitverbs/examples.html. Most of the elders featured on these recordings are no longer with us.

Tlingit is a member of the Na-Dene language family and is spoken in Southeast Alaska and neighboring parts of Canada. There are very few remaining birth speakers of Tlingit, but a large community of second language learners. Access to fluent speakers for language transmission is extremely limited. Words newly documented under this project along with the newly uploaded example sentences with audio recordings are critical additions to the resources available to learners and teachers. The model developed under this project will inform the way the language is taught, clarifying relationships between words and shifting focus toward predictable, productive processes in the language. The model also serves as a guide to lexicographers of other languages which would benefit from a root-based approach. 

The lexicographical model developed under this research, along with the link to the example sentences with audio was disseminated to the Tlingit language community of linguists, teachers, elders, and learners through an email list. These resources, along with audio recordings and field notes from 40 sessions with elder language consultants produced under this project can all be accessed at the Alaska Native Language Archive.

 


Last Modified: 11/15/2022
Modified by: Keri M Eggleston
